title: Meet the college student behind the 'Storm Area 51' Facebook events
text:
LAS VEGAS – What started as a joke and evolved into a viral space oddity has forever changed the life of Matty Roberts.

He’s the 21-year-old video game nerd from Bakersfield, California, who created “Storm Area 51 – They Can’t Stop All of Us,” a globe-grabbing Facebook event that generated more than 2 million RSVPs and led government officials to declare emergencies.

In an interview with the USA TODAY Network, Roberts talked about life before and after the internet spectacle that is coming to the desert as Alienstock – an extraterrestrial-themed music festival set for Sept. 20-22 in Rachel, Nevada, the closest habitation to Area 51.

“It’s been a wild ride,” Roberts said.

Editor's Note: This interview has been edited for length and clarity.

Matty Roberts wants to know what goes on at the mysterious Area 51 in Nevada. More

It started with a slow day at work

I was watching highlights of a Joe Rogan Experience podcast on YouTube while I was at work. It was super slow, so I was clicking through videos – and watching that brought the Area 51 mystery to the forefront of my mind. And on June 27, I was reading online about the Facebook event wars to steal all of Minnesota’s lakes – which are all these meme events. Reading that, already having the Area 51 mystery on my mind, I was like: “I’m going to make a joke event, too!” So I created the “Storm Area 51 – They Can’t Stop All of Us” Facebook post. Over the course of three days, it went absolutely nowhere. Like four people interested, and then it stopped.

Nye County: 'Storm Area 51' event forces second Nevada county to sign emergency declaration

Lincoln County: 'Storm Area 51' event pushes rural Nevada county to declare emergency

Things started getting weird

On July 1, it just started picking up a ton of traction. And on July 2, it got posted on Reddit and blew up again. And after that it started hitting the news. And after it hit the news, it absolutely took off to this crazy, multinational monstrosity of an event. From there, it’s been a really interesting ride.

The FBI showed up to his door

I wasn’t home, so they gave me a call. I let it go to voicemail, because it wasn’t a number I recognized, you know? So I called them back, and the agent answered. They basically wanted to know where I was, when I was going to be home, what I was doing – they just wanted to talk.

So at this point, I do not want to go home at all right now. It kind of freaked me out. But I ended up going back, and they met me there. We sat down and talked for about an hour.

Music festival: After 'Storm Area 51' gets 2 million RSVPs, its creator announces alien-themed music fest

Destination: Belize offers free trips to residents of Nevada town who want to escape 'Storm Area 51'

They asked me a laundry list of questions. Basically, their main concerns were about anybody that was sending death threats that were actually credible and anybody that was actually trying to radicalize this thing. People that think it’s legitimately serious – that we’re actually going to show up and storm the base. People who are planning to bring guns and things. There’s been a few of those people pop up, so I’ve just sent them to the FBI. I don’t want any of that.

I don’t want anyone to get hurt. I don’t think it’s right to threaten the lives of a lot of people, especially with mass shootings for some damn reason being popular right now. I’ve been very wary about that. Safety has been our number one priority. You can’t have a fun, enjoyable event if there’s no safety involved. There will be plenty of law enforcement working outside of the event, and we’ve got a lot of security monitoring this thing to make sure it’s safe for everybody involved.
description: Matty Roberts says the Facebook event started as a joke, but after more than 2 million RSVPs, it's become an extraterrestrial-themed music fest.
